columns.text: On this problem, we are required to answer questions by analyzing scenarios. This mainly discusses about sensitivity analysis.

**Sensitivity Analysis** is a variation on scenario analysis that is useful in pinpointing the areas where forecasting risk is especially severe. It investigates what happens to NPV when only one variable is changed. The main point of this technique is to find out the sensitivity of NPV to changes by only using one variable and freezing all the other variables.

The given details in the problem are as follows: 

<center> 

| **Particulars** | **Amount/Values** | 
|:--|--:| 
| Selling price | $280 per unit | 
| Variable Cost | $185 per unit | 
| Total units | 36,000 | 
| Useful life | 5 years | 
| Fixed Cost | $985,000 | 
| Tax rate | 38 % | 

<center>

The formula for the sensitivity of change in operating cash flow is as follows:

$$\begin{aligned} \text{Sensitivity of change in operating cash flow} &= \dfrac{\text{Change in operating}}{\text{Change in quantity supplied}}\\[15pt]
\end{aligned}
$$

Moving on, let us calculate the sensitivity of change as follows:

$$\begin{aligned} \text{Sensitivity of change in operating cash flow} &= \dfrac{\text{Change in operating cash flow}}{\text{Change in quantity supplied}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\$1,846,000 - \$1,904,900}{35,000 - 36,000}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{-\$58,900}{- 1,000}\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\bf{\$58.90}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the sensitivity of change in operating cash flow is $58.90.

Lastly, the formula for the net present value is shown below:

$$\begin{aligned} \text{NPV} &= \ \text{- Initial investment - Working capital} \\
& \qquad + \text{(Operating cash flow} \times \text{Annuity factor for 5 yrs. at .13)} \\
& \qquad \text{+}\dfrac{\text{Working capital + Salvage value}\times{\text{(1 - Tax rate)}}}{\text{Present value factor for 5 years at .13}} \\[15pt]
\end{aligned}
$$

For the net present value, it is given that:

<center> 

| **Particulars** | **Amount/Values** | 
|:--|--:| 
| Initial Investment | $5,200,000 | 
| Working Capital | $410,000 | 
| Operating Cash Flow | $1,904,000 | 
| Tax Rate | 38% | 
| PV factor | 0.5427 | 
| Annuity factor | 3.517 | 

<center>

We may now compute for the net present value as follows:

$$\begin{aligned} \text{NPV} &= \ \text{- Initial investment - Working capital} \\
& \qquad\text{+ (Operating cash flow}\times{\text{Annuity factor for 5 yrs at .13)}} \\
& \qquad\text{+} \dfrac{\text{Working capital + Salvage value}\times{\text{(1 - Tax rate)}}}{\text{Present value factor for 5 years at .13}} \\[15pt]
& = \ {\text{- \$5,200,000 - \$410,000 + (\$1,904,900}}\times{\text{3.517)}} 
\\
& \qquad\text{+}\dfrac{\text{\$410,000 + \$500,000}\times{\text{(1 - 0.38)}}}{\text{0.5427}} \\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\bf{\$1,480,760.98}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the net present value is $1,480,760.98.

Additionally, the computation for the sensitivity of change in net present value is as follows:

$$\begin{aligned} \text{Sensitivity of change in NPV} &= \dfrac{\text{Change in NPV}}{\text{Change in quantity supplied}}\\[15pt]
\end{aligned}
$$

Moving forward, let us calculate for the sensitivity of change in net present value:

$$\begin{aligned} \text{Sensitivity of change in NPV} &= \dfrac{\text{Change in NPV}}{\text{Change in quantity supplied}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\$1,273,596.06 - \$1,480,760.98}{35,000 - 36,000}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{-\$207,104}{- 1,000}\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\bf{\$207.10}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the sensitivity of change in net present value is $207.10.

Through this computations, we could say that the firm will not desire to supply the quantity level at which the net present value is zero. In this case, the met present value changes to $207.10 for a change in every ton of quality supplied.

Now, let us find out the change in quantity as follows:

$$\begin{aligned} \text{Change in quantity} &= \dfrac{\text{NPV at 35,000 units}}{\text{Sensitivity of NPV}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\$1,273,596.06}{\$207.10}\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\textbf{6,149 units.}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, the change in quantity is 6,149 units.

Lastly, let us reduce the value of the minimum quantity supplied from the normal quantity supplied to obtain the quantity at which the net present value is zero. This means that the firm will not operate below this level of quantity.

$$\begin{aligned} \text{Min quantity} &= \text{Original quantity - Change in quantity}\\[15pt]
&={35,000 - 6,149}\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\textbf{28,851 units}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the minimum quantity is 28,851 units.

Therefore, we may conclude that the firm should not operate below 28,851 units of quantity. At 28,851 units, the net present value will be zero. Hence, if the firm operates below that quantity, the net present value becomes negative.
